ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had to watch films and write a response paper during asynchronous classes.
Films to watch outside of class

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A brilliant, tactical approach to defining the Tragedy. Everything reading was worthwhile. During class, our close reading of passages was the most important feature of the course: every comment and thread could be traced back to our prior discussions of Tragedy. I found it deeply satisfying to study such a manifold artform  always reflecting on what it even means to be a tragic drama  while also getting to experience the inner workings of so many great plays from a diverse background of authors.

I am now a capable reader and appreciator of Greek tragedy. The course has also improved my ability to identify small yet important details about a work, particularly in dialogue. Finally, I am more capable at analyzing the political context of a literary work after taking this course.

This course was a wonderful introduction to the seminal texts of the Western Canon, as studied through the lens of tragedy. I developed my essay writing skills by learning how to consider not only the structure of my argument, but its progression
I gained skills in analytical reading and the literary analysis as a way of writing. I also gained a better understanding of the tragic tradition.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Even though the discussions were very fruitful, I would have preferred it if they were more structured. I also would have liked breakout rooms (~3 people) to have more natural, in-depth discussions.

The readings were excellent. Class discussion was enjoyable and productive. The workload was manageable (the readings were usually pretty short) and there were only a few major assignments.

That said, the grading was unclear. Besides two major papers, we wrote three responses to assigned films on Canvas discussion boards (as well as replies to other discussions). We never received grades or individual feedback on these responses. As for the first major paper (since the second one was our final), we received grades for our first submission but not our second, revised submission. I respect that our work for the class shouldn't purely be motivated by grades, but perhaps some grades being assigned during the semester could ease the uncertainty about my final grade which I feel now.

Strengths included the texts themselves and the lecturer, as well as the feedback we received on essays.
Weaknesses were that we had very limited time with each text, so we only studied it in bits and pieces, that often did not feel cohesive.

The strengths of this course are that it covers such a broad period to look at a relevant literary genre and in the interesting readings. One big weakness was that it's supposed to be at least sort of introductory as an English course, but there seems to be no emphasis on explicitly teaching essential English skills. I think this could best be fixed by creating a drafting process.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Before taking the course, I felt like I knew what to expect more than with my other classes, and that turned out to be true. The seminar style transferred nicely over Zoom. 

The instructor did not have formal office hours, nor did he stick around after class to take questions. Towards the end of the semester, I felt like I would have appreciated formal office hours. That said, he was responsive to emails.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely. As someone majoring in a STEM field but still desiring to perform literary analysis (with a love for the Greeks), English 129 was my best option. The reading is super manageable, the discussions aren't daunting, and the writing process is an important teaching moment. What more could one ask for!
I would recommend this course, especially if you have a background in mythology/classics or another of the topics covered.

Yes! First of all, the assigned literature is excellent. Also one of the hallmarks of tragedy as a genre is an economy of language - this adds to the merit of the work, yes, but it also decreases the workload of the student reader. 

It's generally understood that ENGL 129 is a great choice for students who are interested in DS but can't commit to the full slate of classes. As for me, I wasn't interested in DS when signing up for ENGL 129, but thought that the questions posed in the syllabus were interesting and had no clue how to answer them. I took this class to be introduced to a form of literature I had essentially no experience in - ancient Greek tragedy. Anyone else similarly looking for an introduction to new literature ought to take this course, it's quite manageable, but really worthwhile.
Yes, especially if you are English, Humanities or Comparative Literature Major.

I found the content of the course interesting. So if you want to get an introduction to the wide history of a form that has been very relevant across literature and theater, I'd consider taking this class. I wouldn't recommend this course with Prof. Ellermann. He seemed nice and is obviously very insightful, but he wasn't very clear with his expectations, gave very mediocre feedback, and was bad at facilitating discussions. The course seems like it could be really fascinating and engaging with a different professor though.
